        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 9:26PM MDT until August 14 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS",
        "description": "At 926 PM MDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line\nextending from 3 miles southwest of Otis to 8 miles southeast of Yuma\nto 17 miles northeast of Cope, moving northeast at 35 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to\nroofs, siding, and trees.\n\nThese severe storms will be near...\nYuma around 930 PM MDT.\nEckley around 935 PM MDT.\n\nOther locations impacted by these severe thunderstorms include Joes,\nAbarr, Kirk, Heartstrong, and Vernon.\n\nThis includes Interstate 70 in Colorado between mile markers 391 and\n420.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nContinuous cloud to ground lightning is occurring with these storms.\nMove indoors immediately. Lightning is one of nature's leading\nkillers. Remember, if you can hear thunder, you are close enough to\nbe struck by lightning.",

        "senderName": "NWS Goodland KS",
        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 9:20PM MDT until August 14 at 10:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS",
        "description": "SVRGLD\n\nThe National Weather Service in Goodland has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nWestern Yuma County in northeastern Colorado...\nWestern Kit Carson County in east central Colorado...\n\n* Until 1000 PM MDT.\n\n* At 920 PM MDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line\nextending from 5 miles south of Otis to 10 miles south of Yuma to\n15 miles northeast of Cope, moving northeast at 40 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and nickel size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.\n\n* Severe thunderstorms will be near...\nYuma around 925 PM MDT.\nEckley around 935 PM MDT.\n\nThis includes Interstate 70 in Colorado between mile markers 391 and\n420.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nLarge hail, damaging wind, and continuous cloud to ground lightning\nare occurring with these storms. Move indoors immediately. Lightning\nis one of nature's leading killers. Remember, if you can hear\nthunder, you are close enough to be struck by lightning.",

        "event": "Flash Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Raleigh NC",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 11:09PM EDT until August 15 at 2:15AM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC",
        "description": "FFWRAH\n\nThe National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nCentral Wake County in central North Carolina...\n\n* Until 215 AM EDT.\n\n* At 1109 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain across the warned area. Up to 2 inches of rain have\nfallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 2 inches are possible in\nthe warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban\nareas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as\nother poor drainage and low-lying areas.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nRaleigh, Cary, Garner, RDU International, Apex, Morrisville,\nKnightdale, William B Umstead State Park and Carpenter.\n\nThis includes the following streams and drainages...\nWalnut Creek, Big Branch, Beaver Creek, Southwest Prong Beaverdam\nCreek, Swift Creek, Crabtree Creek, Hare Snipe Creek, Reedy Creek,\nHarris Creek, Long Branch, Honeycutt Creek, Kit Creek, Lynn\nBranch, Perry Creek, Lower Barton Creek, Pigeon House Branch,\nRocky Branch, Neuse River, Bachelor Branch, Brier Creek, Northeast\nCreek, Turkey Creek, Beaverdam Creek, Speight Branch, Marks Creek,\nColes Branch, Jack Branch and Middle Creek.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding.",
        "response": "Avoid",
        "parameters": {
          "AWIPSidentifier": [
            "FFWRAH"
          ],
          "WMOidentifier": [
            "WGUS52 KRAH 150309"
          ],
          "flashFloodDetection": [

          ],

        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 9:08PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS",
        "description": "At 908 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking gusty showers along a line\nextending from 7 miles east of Arriba to 3 miles east of Flagler to\n14 miles south of Seibert.         "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.",

        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 9:02PM MDT until August 14 at 9:15PM MDT by NWS North Platte NE",
        "description": "At 902 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 15 miles south of\nRushville, moving northeast at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to\nroofs, siding, and trees.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nSnow Lake, Diamond Lake, Smith Lake State Wildlife Management Area,\nIntersection of Highway 87 and Antelope Road, and Walgren Lake State\nRecreation Area.\n\nThis includes the following highways...\nHighway 20 near mile marker 80.\nHighway 250 between mile markers 4 and 27.",

        "senderName": "NWS Raleigh NC",
        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 10:55PM EDT until August 15 at 1:00AM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of central North Carolina, including the\nfollowing counties, Franklin, Johnston, Nash and Wake.\n\n* WHEN...Until 100 AM EDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\nOverflowing poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 1055 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Up to 2 inches of rain have\nfallen.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nRaleigh, Durham, Cary, Garner, Zebulon, RDU International,\nApex, Morrisville, Knightdale, Wendell, Rolesville,\nMiddlesex, Lake Wheeler, William B Umstead State Park, Pilot,\nEmit, Research Triangle, Carpenter and Jordan Lake.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding.",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS North Platte NE",
        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 8:54PM MDT until August 14 at 9:15PM MDT by NWS North Platte NE",
        "description": "At 853 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 17 miles southeast\nof Hay Springs, moving northeast at 35 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to\nroofs, siding, and trees.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nAntioch, Snow Lake, Wickson Lake, Diamond Lake, Krause Lake, Smith\nLake State Wildlife Management Area, Intersection of Highway 87 and\nAntelope Road, and Walgren Lake State Recreation Area.\n\nThis includes the following highways...\nHighway 20 near mile marker 80.\nHighway 250 between mile markers 4 and 27.\nHighway 2 between mile markers 99 and 102.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.",
        "response": "Shelter",

        "description": "* WHAT...For the Friday Heat Advisory, heat index values mainly 100\nto 105 expected.         "description": "* WHAT...For the Friday Heat Advisory, heat index values mainly 100\nto 105 expected. For the Saturday Heat Advisory, heat index values\nmainly 103 to 109 expected.\n\n* WHERE...Portions of central, east central, and south central\nNebraska.\n\n* WHEN...For the first Heat Advisory, from noon to 8 PM CDT Friday.\nFor the second Heat Advisory, from noon to 8 PM CDT Saturday.\n\n* IMPACTS...Hot temperatures and high humidity may cause heat\nillnesses.",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN",
        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 9:45PM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in\nMinnesota...\n\nMinnesota River at Montevideo affecting Chippewa, Yellow Medicine\nand Lac qui Parle Counties.\n\n.There are chances for thunderstorms this weekend. A few storms\ncould produce heavy rain, which could prolong the flooding along the\nMinnesota River.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Minnesota River at Montevideo.\n\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Low lying areas and some roads along the\nriver begin flooding, along with some basements of houses along\nthe river.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 900 PM CDT Thursday, the stage was 15.1 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 900 PM CDT Thursday was 15.1 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to remain near 15 ft.\n- Flood stage is 14.0 feet.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "event": "Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Newport/Morehead City NC",
        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 10:42PM EDT until August 16 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North\nCarolina...\n\nContentnea Creek Near Hookerton affecting Pitt, Lenoir and Greene\nCounties.\n\nFor the Contentnea Creek...including Hookerton...Minor flooding is\nforecast.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Contentnea Creek near Hookerton.\n\n* WHEN...Until early Saturday morning.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Minor flooding of low lying areas adjacent\nto creek can be expected. Several homes threatened by water in\nnorthwest Greene County near HWY 58.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 10:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 13.1 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 10:00 PM EDT Thursday was 13.1 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 13.1\nfeet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below\nflood stage tomorrow evening.\n- Flood stage is 13.0 feet.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nMotorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\ncars through flooded areas.\n\nAdditional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps.\n\nThe next statement will be issued Friday evening at 1100 PM EDT.",
        "response": "Avoid",
        "parameters": {
          "AWIPSidentifier": [
            "FLSMHX"
          ],
          "WMOidentifier": [
            "WGUS82 KMHX 150242"
          ],

        "senderName": "NWS Grand Forks ND",
        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 9:39PM CDT until August 14 at 10:45PM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND",
        "description": "SVRFGF\n\nThe National Weather Service in Grand Forks has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nNorthwestern Polk County in northwestern Minnesota...\nWest central Pennington County in northwestern Minnesota...\n\n* Until 1045 PM CDT.\n\n* At 938 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Sherack, or\n13 miles northeast of Grand Forks, moving southeast at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Ping pong ball size hail and 60 mph wind gusts.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect hail\ndamage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles. Expect\nwind damage to roofs, siding, and trees.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nEuclid, Angus, Tabor, Key West, and Sherack.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.",

        "event": "Special Weather Statement",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 9:37PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "description": "At 937 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along\na line extending from near Jasper to 7 miles northeast of Junction.\nMovement was south at 5 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nDe Ridder, Jasper, Newton, Rosepine, Merryville, Burkeville,\nFarrsville, Burr Ferry, Jamestown, Roganville, Harrisburg, Junction,\nStringtown, Wiergate, and Evans.",
        "instruction": "Torrential rainfall is also occurring with these storms and may lead\nto localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\nroadways.\n\nThese storms may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio\nstations and available television stations for additional information\nand possible warnings from the National Weather Service.",
        "response": "Execute",
        "parameters": {
          "AWIPSidentifier": [
            "SPSLCH"
          ],

          ],

        "event": "Flash Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 9:36PM CDT until August 15 at 12:45AM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "description": "FFWLCH\n\nThe National Weather Service in Lake Charles has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nNorth Central Beauregard Parish in southwestern Louisiana...\nSouthwestern Vernon Parish in west central Louisiana...\nNorthern Newton County in southeastern Texas...\n\n* Until 1245 AM CDT.\n\n* At 936 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 3 inches of\nrain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 3 inches are\npossible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected\nto begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban\nareas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as\nother poor drainage and low-lying areas.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nDe Ridder, Newton, Rosepine, Burkeville, Fort Polk, Junction,\nStringtown, Farrsville, Jamestown, Evans, Wiergate and Pickering.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "description": "At 834 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm 8\nmiles southwest of Lisco, or 20 miles west of Oshkosh, moving\nnortheast at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph and pea size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\npossible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nOshkosh, Lisco, and Sugar Loaf Hill.",
        "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\n\nThis storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio\nstations and available television stations for additional information\nand possible warnings from the National Weather Service.",

        "description": "SVRLBF\n\nThe National Weather Service in North Platte has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nSouthwestern Sheridan County in the Panhandle of Nebraska...\n\n* Until 915 PM MDT.\n\n* At 825 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Alliance,\nmoving northeast at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage\nto roofs, siding, and trees.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nEllsworth, Antioch, Snow Lake, Wickson Lake, Diamond Lake,\nLakeside, Krause Lake, Kennedy Lake, Smith Lake State Wildlife\nManagement Area, Intersection of Highway 87 and Antelope Road, and\nWalgren Lake State Recreation Area.\n\nThis includes the following highways...\nHighway 20 near mile marker 80.\nHighway 250 between mile markers 1 and 27.\nHighway 2 between mile markers 96 and 121.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Wilmington NC",
        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 10:17PM EDT until August 16 at 2:40PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North\nCarolina...\n\nCape Fear River At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3 affecting\nBladen and Cumberland Counties.\n\n...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South\nCarolina...North Carolina...\n\nWaccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County.\n\nWaccamaw River near Longs affecting Columbus, Brunswick and Horry\nCounties.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Cape Fear River at William O Huske Lock And Dam 3.\n\n* WHEN...Until early Saturday afternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 45.0 feet, Flood waters will affect lowlands along\nthe east bank of the river with some minor overflow along the west\nbank.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 9:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 45.6 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 45.6\nfeet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below\nflood stage tomorrow evening.\n- Flood stage is 42.0 feet.\n- weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\ncars through flooded areas.\n\nStay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio,\ntelevision, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at water.noaa.gov/wfo/ilm .\n\nThe next statement will be issued by Friday afternoon.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "senderName": "NWS Wilmington NC",
        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 10:17PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC",
        "description": "...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in North\nCarolina...\n\nNortheast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County.\n\n* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.\n\n* WHERE...Northeast Cape Fear River near Burgaw.\n\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Water deepens on the lowest portions of\nRiver Bend Road and River Birch Road.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 9:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 8.5 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 8.7\nfeet tomorrow evening.\n- Advisory stage is 8.0 feet.\n- Flood stage is 10.0 feet.\n- weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Stay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio,\ntelevision, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at water.noaa.gov/wfo/ilm .\n\nThe next statement will be issued by Friday afternoon.",

        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 10:17PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North\nCarolina...\n\nCape Fear River At William O Huske Lock And Dam 3 affecting\nBladen and Cumberland Counties.\n\n...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South\nCarolina...North Carolina...\n\nWaccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County.\n\nWaccamaw River near Longs affecting Columbus, Brunswick and Horry\nCounties.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Waccamaw River at Conway.\n\n* WHEN...Until further notice.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Flooding will worsen in Lees Landing,\nRiverfront South, Pitch Landing, and Savannah Bluff. Flooding will\nalso worsen along Waccamaw CIR, Riverside DR, and in low areas\nalong Gray Oak DR. Flood waters will begin to affect Black Moss DR\nand Cypress Flat. Depot RD, New RD, and Jackson Bluff RD may begin\nto flood.  The lowest homes on Riverside DR north of Conway may be\naffected.  Witch Golf Course may begin to flood. Swamps will be\nheavily flooded.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 9:15 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 11.5 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 11.9 feet Monday\nevening. Additional rises are possible thereafter.\n- Flood stage is 11.0 feet.\n- weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\ncars through flooded areas.\n\nStay tuned to further developments by listening to your local radio,\ntelevision, or NOAA Weather Radio for further information.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at water.noaa.gov/wfo/ilm .\n\nThe next statement will be issued by Friday afternoon.",

        "senderName": "NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI",
        "headline": "Flood Watch issued August 14 at 9:08PM CDT until August 18 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI",
        "description": "...The Flood Watch is extended for the following river in Illinois...\nWisconsin...\n\nFox River Lower Near New Munster affecting Kenosha and Lake\nCounties.\n\n* WHAT...Flooding is possible.\n\n* WHERE...Fox River Lower near New Munster.\n\n* WHEN...From late Saturday night to early Monday afternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 11.0 feet, Floodwaters begin to affect 77th St. in\nthe Town of Wheatland. Floodwaters are near some homes along\nRiverside Dr, Shorewood Dr, and Highway W in the Village of Salem\nLakes and Town of Wheatland areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 8:00 PM CDT Thursday the stage was 9.6 feet.\n- Forecast...Flood stage may be reached early Sunday morning.\n- Flood stage is 11.0 feet.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "If you are in the watch area, remain alert to possible flooding.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov.\n\nThe next statement will be issued late tonight at 515 AM CDT.",
        "response": "Prepare",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI",
        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 9:07PM CDT until August 16 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Milwaukee/Sullivan WI",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning is extended for the following river in\nWisconsin...\n\nFox River Lower At Waukesha affecting Waukesha County.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\nThis approaches the flood of record.\n\n* WHERE...Fox River Lower at Waukesha.\n\n* WHEN...Until early Saturday afternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Water is over the banks of Frame Park and\nfloodwaters are at least 2 feet deep on land near the shoreline.\nAbout one half mile south of downtown Waukesha, water is 2 to 3\nfeet deep and covering much of the back yards of 6 or 7 homes in\nthe Bethesda Court area of Waukesha.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 8:00 PM CDT Thursday the stage was 7.1 feet.\n- Bankfull stage is 5.0 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 8:00 PM CDT Thursday was 7.7 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage\nSaturday morning and continue falling to 4.0 feet Thursday,\nAugust 21.\n- Flood stage is 6.0 feet.\n- Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of\n7.0 feet on 07/12/2017.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive\ncars through flooded areas.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov.\n\nThe next statement will be issued Friday morning at 915 AM CDT.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 9:05PM CDT until August 14 at 9:45PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "description": "SVRLCH\n\nThe National Weather Service in Lake Charles has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nNorth central Beauregard Parish in southwestern Louisiana...\nSouthwestern Vernon Parish in west central Louisiana...\nEast central Newton County in southeastern Texas...\n\n* Until 945 PM CDT.\n\n* At 905 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 8 miles southeast\nof Burr Ferry, or 9 miles west of Rosepine, moving southwest at 15\nmph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nDe Ridder, Rosepine, Junction, and Evans.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nTorrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to\nflash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.",

        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 7:59PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD",
        "description": "At 759 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong\nthunderstorms over Belle Ayr Mine, or 13 miles south of Gillette,\nmoving northeast at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and pea size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\npossible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nGillette, Coal Creek Mine, Caballo Mine, Belle Ayr Mine, Wyodak Mine,\nRozet, Camplex Event Facility, and Gillette Airport.\n\nThis includes Interstate 90 in Wyoming between Mile Markers 122 and\n153.",
        "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.",

        "description": "SVRFGF\n\nThe National Weather Service in Grand Forks has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nNorthwestern Polk County in northwestern Minnesota...\n\n* Until 945 PM CDT.\n\n* At 858 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Tabor, or 15\nmiles northeast of Grand Forks, moving southeast at 25 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected.         "senderName": "NWS Flagstaff AZ",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 6:52PM MST until August 14 at 9:45PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ",
        "description": "FFWFGZ\n\nThe National Weather Service in Flagstaff has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nGila County in east central Arizona...\nYavapai County in west central Arizona...\n\n* Until 945 PM MST.\n\n* At 652 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 3 inches of\nrain have fallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly.\n\nHAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms\nproducing flash flooding.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams,\nnormally dry washes, urban areas, highways, streets\nand underpasses.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nChalk Mountain and Pine Mountain Wilderness.\n\nThis includes the following creeks, washes and rivers...\nTangle Creek, Wet Bottom Creek, Bishop Creek, Spring Wash, Pigeon\nCreek, Hardscrabble Creek, Houston Creek, Red Creek, Verde River,\nFossil Creek, Middle Red Creek, Dry Wash, Sycamore Creek and Horse\nCreek.",
        "instruction": "Flooding of washes and creeks will occur, some dirt roads will\nbecome muddy and impassable. Paved roads and underpasses could\nbecome flooded as well.\n\nLow water crossings will become dangerous in heavy rain. Do not\nattempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.",
        "response": "Avoid",

            "FFWFGZ"
          ],

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS North Platte NE",
        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 7:48PM MDT by NWS North Platte NE",
        "description": "At 748 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over\nBerea, or near Alliance, moving northeast at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph and half inch hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\npossible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nSnow Lake, Wickson Lake, Krause Lake, and Diamond Lake.\n\nThis includes the following highways...\nHighway 250 between mile markers 5 and 19.\nHighway 2 near mile marker 96.",
        "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\n\nThis storm may intensify, so be certain to monitor local radio\nstations and available television stations for additional information\nand possible warnings from the National Weather Service.",

        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 8:46PM CDT until August 14 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "description": "At 846 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near New Llano, or 7\nmiles north of Rosepine, moving southeast at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nLeesville, Rosepine, Fort Polk, New Llano, and Pickering.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nTorrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to\nflash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.",

        "event": "Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Columbia SC",
        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 9:44PM EDT until August 17 at 12:48PM EDT by NWS Columbia SC",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South\nCarolina...\n\nCongaree River At Congaree River at Congaree NP Near Gadsden\naffecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.\n\n...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South\nCarolina...\n\nCongaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Lexington, Richland\nand Calhoun Counties.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Congaree River at Carolina Eastman.\n\n* WHEN...Until early Sunday afternoon.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 115.0 feet, Flooding occurs in low lying areas of the\nCarolina Eastman Facility and at the Congaree National Park.\nAt 119.0 feet, Extensive flooding occurs in the Congaree National\nPark. Some area farmland is flooded. Minor flooding occurs at the\nCarolina Eastman Facility.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 8:07 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 118.3 feet.\n- Bankfull stage is 114.0 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage\nearly Saturday afternoon and continue falling to 110.5 feet\nTuesday evening.\n- Flood stage is 115.0 feet.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Residents and those with interests near the river should monitor\nrising water levels and take action if necessary.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov.\n\nThe next statement will be issued Friday morning at 945 AM EDT.",
        "response": "Avoid",
        "parameters": {

          ],

        "status": "Actual",

        "urgency": "Immediate",
        "event": "Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Columbia SC",
        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 9:44PM EDT until August 19 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Columbia SC",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South\nCarolina...\n\nCongaree River At Congaree River at Congaree NP Near Gadsden\naffecting Richland and Calhoun Counties.\n\n...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South\nCarolina...\n\nCongaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Lexington, Richland\nand Calhoun Counties.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree River at Congaree NP Near\nGadsden.\n\n* WHEN...Until early Tuesday morning.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins in the Congaree National\nPark. This will begin to produce flooding of portions of the lower\nboardwalk.\nAt 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes\nflooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes\nflooded by Cedar Creek.\nAt 18.0 feet, Several homes in the Sandy Run subdivision along the\nriver become flooded. At 18 feet the river covers the Weston Lake\noverlook in the Congaree National Park. Between 18 and 18.5 feet\nthe river begins to cover sections of the elevated boardwalk.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 9:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 17.1 feet.\n- Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage\nearly Monday morning and continue falling to 11.4 feet\nTuesday evening.\n- Flood stage is 15.0 feet.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Residents and those with interests near the river should monitor\nrising water levels and take action if necessary.\n\nCaution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov.\n\nThe next statement will be issued Friday morning at 945 AM EDT.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "description": "...The Flood Advisory continues for the following rivers in South\nCarolina...\n\nCongaree River At Congaree River at Columbia affecting Lexington\nand Richland Counties.\n\n* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.\n\n* WHERE...Congaree River at Congaree River at Columbia.\n\n* WHEN...Until Saturday evening.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Flooding occurs in flood prone areas near\nand downstream from Columbia. Flooding also occurs on parts of the\nCayce and West Columbia river walk.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 9:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 10.5 feet.\n- Bankfull stage is 19.0 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 5.6 feet Tuesday\nevening.\n- Action stage is 10.0 feet.\n- Flood stage is 19.0 feet.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov.\n\nThe next statement will be issued Friday morning at 945 AM EDT.",

        "description": "At 941 PM EDT, Doppler radar was tracking a line of thunderstorms\nwith heavy rain and frequent lightning extending from near\nWake Forest and Louisburg to Halifax, moving southeast at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts in excess of 30 mph.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nRocky Mount, Roanoke Rapids, Tarboro, Smithfield, Nashville,\nLouisburg, Halifax, Wilson, Wake Forest, and Zebulon.",
        "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\n\nTorrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead to\nlocalized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\nroadways.",

        "headline": "Special Marine Warning issued August 14 at 9:38PM EDT until August 14 at 10:45PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC",
        "description": "SMWMHX\n\nThe National Weather Service in Newport has issued a\n\n* Special Marine Warning for...\nS of Cape Lookout NC to Surf City NC out to 20 nm...\nWaters from Cape Lookout  to Surf City NC from 20 to 40 nm...\n\n* Until 1045 PM EDT.\n\n* At 938 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms capable of producing\nwaterspouts were located along a line extending from 8 nm southeast\nof Topsail Boxcars to 12 nm northeast of Wr2 to 16 nm southeast of\nAr355 to 29 nm southwest of Big Ten Fathom, moving northeast at 20\nknots.\n\nHAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts 34 knots or greater.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally\nhazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly\nhigher winds and suddenly higher waves.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nBogue Inlet, Ar355, Ar345, and New River Inlet.",
        "instruction": "Thunderstorms can produce sudden waterspouts. Waterspouts can easily\noverturn boats and create locally hazardous seas. Seek safe harbor\nimmediately.",

        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 7:37PM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY",
        "description": "At 737 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong\nthunderstorms along a line extending from near Box Butte Campground\nto 9 miles northeast of Hemingford to 7 miles southwest of Alliance.\nMovement was east at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and half inch hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\npossible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nAlliance, Hemingford, Box Butte Campground, Box Butte County\nFairgrounds, Box Butte Reservoir, Berea, Alliance Municipal Airport,\nWild Horse Butte, Marsland, and Box Butte Dam.",
        "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.",
        "response": "Execute",

        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 7:29PM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD",
        "description": "At 729 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong\nthunderstorms 8 miles northeast of Savageton, or 15 miles northwest\nof Wright, moving north at 35 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nWright, Coal Creek Mine, Caballo Mine, Belle Ayr Mine, Reno Junction,\nHilight Gas Plant, Black Thunder Mine, and Savageton.\n\nThis includes Interstate 90 in Wyoming between Mile Markers 97 and\n110.",

        "senderName": "NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 8:26PM CDT until August 14 at 9:00PM CDT by NWS Lake Charles LA",
        "description": "SVRLCH\n\nThe National Weather Service in Lake Charles has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nSouthwestern Vernon Parish in west central Louisiana...\n\n* Until 900 PM CDT.\n\n* At 825 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near New Llano, or\nnear Leesville, moving southeast at 10 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nLeesville, Rosepine, Fort Polk, New Llano, and Pickering.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nTorrential rainfall is occurring with this storm, and may lead to\nflash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.",
        "response": "Shelter",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Wakefield VA",
        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 9:21PM EDT until August 15 at 12:30AM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...Portions of northeast North Carolina, including the\nfollowing county, Northampton and southeast Virginia, including\nthe following county and independent city, City of Emporia and\nGreensville.\n\n* WHEN...Until 1230 AM EDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 921 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain\nhave fallen.\n- Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are expected\nover the area. This additional rain will result in minor\nflooding.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nEmporia, Dahlia, Gaston, Barley, Green Plain, Brink, Turners\nCrossroads, Slates Corner, Pleasant Hill, Lanes Corner,\nEmporia Reservoir, Gum Forks, Durand, Emporia Airport and\nVultare.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding. Do not stay in areas subject to flooding when\nwater begins rising.",
        "response": "Avoid",
        "parameters": {
          "AWIPSidentifier": [
            "FLSAKQ"
          ],
          "WMOidentifier": [

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Flagstaff AZ",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 6:13PM MST until August 14 at 8:15PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ",
        "description": "At 613 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy\nrain over the West Fire scar. Between 0.75 and 2 inches of rain have\nfallen. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing\nflash flooding in and around the West Fire scar.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around\nthe West Fire scar.\n\nSome locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nGeronimo Estates and Flowing Springs.\n\nThis includes the following recreation areas and campgrounds...\nGeronimo Boy Scout Camp.\n\nThis includes the following creeks, washes and rivers...\nWest Webber Creek.",
        "instruction": "Flooding of washes and creeks will occur, some dirt roads will\nbecome muddy and impassable. Paved roads and underpasses could\nbecome flooded as well.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "description": "SVRFGF\n\nThe National Weather Service in Grand Forks has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nSouthwestern Marshall County in northwestern Minnesota...\nNorth central Grand Forks County in northeastern North Dakota...\nSoutheastern Walsh County in northeastern North Dakota...\n\n* Until 845 PM CDT.\n\n* At 808 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located over Ardoch, or 13\nmiles south of Grafton, moving east at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and half dollar size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage\nto roofs, siding, and trees.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nMinto, Alvarado, Oslo, Forest River, Warsaw, Ardoch, and Voss.",

        "description": "At 806 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along\na line extending from near Slagle to near Leesville. Movement was\nsouthwest at 5 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nLeesville, Rosepine, Fort Polk, Slagle, New Llano, Cravens, and\nPickering.",
        "instruction": "Torrential rainfall is also occurring with these storms and may lead\nto localized flooding.         "event": "Flash Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Wakefield VA",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 9:05PM EDT until August 14 at 10:15PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "FFWAKQ\n\nThe National Weather Service in Wakefield has extended the\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nWest Central Isle of Wight County in southeastern Virginia...\nNortheastern Southampton County in southeastern Virginia...\nSouth Central Surry County in southeastern Virginia...\nEastern Sussex County in southeastern Virginia...\n\n* Until 1015 PM EDT.\n\n* At 905 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 3 inches of\nrain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts up to 0.5 inches are\npossible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected\nto begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban\nareas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as\nother poor drainage and low-lying areas.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nWakefield, Ivor, Ellis Fork, Booth Fork and Raynor.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.\n\nPlease report flooding by calling 757-899-2415, posting to the NWS\nWakefield Facebook page, or using X @NWSWAKEFIELDVA.",
        "response": "Avoid",
        "parameters": {
          "AWIPSidentifier": [
            "FFWAKQ"
          ],

            "WGUS51 KAKQ 150105"
          ],

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Wakefield VA",
        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 9:02PM EDT until August 15 at 12:15AM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of eastern Virginia, including the following\ncounty, Northampton.\n\n* WHEN...Until 1215 AM EDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 902 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Up to 2 inches of rain have\nfallen.\n- Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected\nover the area. This additional rain will result in minor\nflooding.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nExmore, Nassawadox, Willis Wharf, Franktown, Birdsnest,\nWardtown, Jamesville, Silver Beach and Machipongo.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding. Do not stay in areas subject to flooding when\nwater begins rising.",

        "description": "At 700 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking an area of strong\nthunderstorms extending from 12 miles north of Westplains to near\nPrewitt Reservoir, or extending from 15 miles south of Kimball to 18\nmiles northwest of Akron, moving east at 20 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and pea size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.         "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 6:59PM MDT by NWS Salt Lake City UT",
        "description": "At 659 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along\na line extending from Syracuse to Salt Lake City.         "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 6:53PM MDT by NWS Pocatello ID",
        "description": "At 652 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over\nnortheastern Bear Lake Idaho Portion, moving northeast at 30 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts in excess of 35 mph.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nBear Lake Idaho Portion, Saint Charles, Dingle, Border Summit,\nGeneva, and Pegram.",
        "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\n\nIf on or near Bear Lake, get out of the water and move indoors or\ninside a vehicle. Strong winds will create rough chop.\nRemember, lightning can strike out to 10 miles from the parent\nthunderstorm. If you can hear thunder, you are close enough to be\nstruck by lightning. Move to safe shelter now! Do not be caught on\nthe water in a thunderstorm.",

        "description": "SMWMHX\n\nThe National Weather Service in Newport has issued a\n\n* Special Marine Warning for...\nS of Cape Lookout NC to Surf City NC out to 20 nm...\nWaters from Cape Lookout  to Surf City NC from 20 to 40 nm...\n\n* Until 945 PM EDT.\n\n* At 846 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms capable of producing\nwaterspouts were located along a line extending from 13 nm\nnortheast of Wr2 to 20 nm southeast of Ar355, moving northeast at\n10 knots.\n\nHAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts 34 knots or greater.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally\nhazardous seas.         "senderName": "NWS Wakefield VA",
        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 8:32PM EDT until August 14 at 10:30PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of southeast Virginia, including the following\ncounty and independent city, City of Franklin and Southampton.\n\n* WHEN...Until 1030 PM EDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 832 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 1.5 inches of\nrain have fallen.\n- Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are expected\nover the area. This additional rain will result in minor\nflooding.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nFranklin, Suffolk, Hunterdale, Handsom and Sunbeam.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding. Do not stay in areas subject to flooding when\nwater begins rising.",

        "event": "Special Weather Statement",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Miami FL",
        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 8:32PM EDT by NWS Miami FL",
        "description": "At 832 PM EDT, National Weather Service meteorologists were tracking\na strong thunderstorm near Orangetree, or near Ave Maria, moving west\nat 10 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts of 45 to 50 mph.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nNaples, Golden Gate Estates, Ave Maria, Naples Park, Orangetree, Big\nCorkscrew Island, Vineyards, Golden Gate, North Naples, East Naples,\nPelican Bay, and Quail Creek Estate.",
        "instruction": "These winds can down small tree limbs and branches, and blow around\nunsecured small objects. Seek shelter in a safe building until the\nstorm passes.\n\nTorrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead to\nlocalized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\nroadways.\n\nFrequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.\nLightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe\nshelter inside a building or vehicle.",
        "response": "Execute",
        "parameters": {

          ],

        "senderName": "NWS Wilmington NC",
        "headline": "Special Marine Warning issued August 14 at 8:22PM EDT until August 14 at 9:30PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC",
        "description": "SMWILM\n\nThe National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a\n\n* Special Marine Warning for...\nCoastal waters from Surf City to Cape Fear NC out 20 nm...\nWaters from Surf City to Cape Fear NC from 20 to 40 nm...\n\n* Until 930 PM EDT.\n\n* At 822 PM EDT, a severe thunderstorm capable of producing\nwaterspouts was located near Sheepshead Rock, moving northeast at\n20 knots.\n\nHAZARD...Waterspouts and wind gusts 34 knots or greater.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Waterspouts can easily overturn boats and create locally\nhazardous seas. Small craft could be damaged in briefly\nhigher winds and suddenly higher waves.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nDredge Wreck, 10 Mile Boxcars, 10 Mile Rocks, School House Reef,\nand Wr2.",
        "instruction": "Boaters should seek safe harbor immediately until these storms pass.\nIf caught on the open water, prepare for deteriorating conditions.\nMake sure you and your crew are wearing properly fitted life jackets.\n\nThunderstorms can produce sudden waterspouts. Waterspouts can easily\noverturn boats and create locally hazardous seas. Seek safe harbor\nimmediately.",

        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 6:19PM MDT until August 14 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO",
        "description": "SVRBOU\n\nThe National Weather Service in Denver has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nSouthwestern Logan County in northeastern Colorado...\nNortheastern Morgan County in northeastern Colorado...\nNorth Central Washington County in northeastern Colorado...\nEastern Weld County in northeastern Colorado...\n\n* Until 700 PM MDT.\n\n* At 619 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 4 miles east of\nAntelope Springs, or 15 miles northeast of Fort Morgan, moving\neast at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Golf ball size hail and 70 mph wind gusts.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...People and animals outdoors will be injured. Expect\nhail damage to roofs, siding, windows, and vehicles.\nExpect considerable tree damage. Wind damage is also\nlikely to mobile homes, roofs, and outbuildings. Hail\nmay accumulate on roadways causing hazardous travel.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nMerino, Hillrose, Willard, Snyder, Prewitt Reservoir, Messex and\nUnion.",
        "instruction": "Anyone outdoors should move to shelter inside a well-built structure\nand stay away from windows. This storm is capable of producing\nwidespread damaging winds and dangerous hail.\n\nTorrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead\nto flash flooding.         "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Wakefield VA",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 8:18PM EDT until August 14 at 10:15PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "FFWAKQ\n\nThe National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nYork County in southeastern Virginia...\nThe City of Hampton in southeastern Virginia...\nThe City of Newport News in southeastern Virginia...\nThe City of Poquoson in southeastern Virginia...\n\n* Until 1015 PM EDT.\n\n* At 818 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain across the warned area. Up to 2 inches of rain have\nfallen. The expected rainfall rate is 0.75 to 1.75 inches in 30\nminutes. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban\nareas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as\nother poor drainage and low-lying areas.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nNewport News, Hampton, Langley AFB, Christopher Newport\nUniversity, Patrick Henry Field, Hampton University, Seaford,\nNorthampton, Tabb, Beaconsdale, Buckroe Beach, Grand View,\nDenbigh, Fort Monroe, Langley View, Messick, Dare, Hilton Village,\nPlum Tree Island Refuge and Raleigh Terrace.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding. Do not stay in areas subject to flooding when\nwater begins rising.\n\nBe aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.\n\nPlease report flooding by calling 757-899-2415, posting to the NWS\nWakefield Facebook page, or using X @NWSWAKEFIELDVA.",
        "response": "Avoid",
        "parameters": {

          ],

          ],

        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 5:17PM MST until August 14 at 8:15PM MST by NWS Flagstaff AZ",
        "description": "FFWFGZ\n\nThe National Weather Service in Flagstaff has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nThe West Fire scar in...\nGila County in east central Arizona...\nCoconino County in north central Arizona...\n\n* Until 815 PM MST.\n\n* At 517 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain over the West Fire scar. Between 0.75 and 1.5 inches of\nrain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 0.75\ninches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing\nor expected to begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms\nproducing flash flooding in and around the West Fire\nscar.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around\nthe West Fire scar.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nGeronimo Estates and Flowing Springs.\n\nThis includes the following recreation areas and campgrounds...\nGeronimo Boy Scout Camp.\n\nThis includes the following creeks, washes and rivers...\nWest Webber Creek.",
        "instruction": "Flooding of washes and creeks will occur, some dirt roads will\nbecome muddy and impassable. Paved roads and underpasses could\nbecome flooded as well.",

        "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued August 14 at 4:49PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA",
        "description": "An Air Quality Alert has been issued by the following agencies:\n\nIdaho Department of Environmental Quality in Coeur d'Alene\n\n...AIR QUALITY ADVISORY FROM THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL\nQUALITY FOR Boundary, Bonner, & Shoshone...\n\n* WHAT...Air Quality Advisory because of degraded air quality. Air\nQuality Index is forecast to be Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups.\n\n* WHERE...Boundary, Bonner, & Shoshone counties.\n\n* WHEN...Until 12pm PST 8/15/2025.\n\n* IMPACTS...Members of sensitive groups may experience health\neffects. The general public is less likely to be affected.",
        "instruction": "Air pollutants can cause breathing difficulties for children, the\nelderly, as well as persons with respiratory problems. Those\nindividuals who are sensitive to increased particulate matter or\nsmoke are encouraged to avoid prolonged or strenuous outdoor activity\nduring this advisory. Open burning is prohibited by air quality rule.\nIt is also recommended that all other individuals limit prolonged or\nstrenuous activity outdoors.\n\nTHIS STATEMENT IS ISSUED BY THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL\nQUALITY, AIR QUALITY GROUP\n\nFOR MORE INFORMATION, CONTACT DEQ's Coeur d'Alene Regional Office at\n(208) 769-1422.",

        "senderName": "NWS Memphis TN",
        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 7:02PM CDT by NWS Memphis TN",
        "description": "At 702 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm near\nKolola Springs, or 10 miles southeast of Aberdeen. This thunderstorm\nwas nearly stationary.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and half inch hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\npossible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nAmory, Aberdeen, Prairie, New Wren, Gattman, Binford, Sipsey Fork,\nNew Hamilton, Becker, Quincy, Wise Gap, Athens, Wren, Strong, East\nAberdeen, Muldon, and Greenwood Springs.",
        "instruction": "Torrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead to\nlocalized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\nroadways.\n\nFrequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.\nLightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe\nshelter inside a building or vehicle.",
        "response": "Execute",

          ],

        "description": "At 559 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking gusty showers along a line\nextending from near Register Cliff State Historic Site to near\nSlater.         "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.",

        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 5:59PM MDT until August 14 at 6:45PM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO",
        "description": "SVRPUB\n\nThe National Weather Service in Pueblo has issued a\n\n* Severe Thunderstorm Warning for...\nWest central Kiowa County in southeastern Colorado...\nNortheastern Crowley County in southeastern Colorado...\n\n* Until 645 PM MDT.\n\n* At 559 PM MDT, a severe thunderstorm was located 11 miles north of\nSugar City, or 28 miles north of La Junta, moving north at 25 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected.         "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 5:56PM MDT by NWS Cheyenne WY",
        "description": "At 555 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking a cluster of strong\nthunderstorms along a line extending from near Torrington to near\nHenry to near Lyman.         "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.",

        "headline": "Air Quality Alert issued August 14 at 4:49PM PDT by NWS Spokane WA",
        "description": "An Air Quality Alert has been issued by the following agencies:\n\nIdaho Department of Environmental Quality in Coeur d'Alene\n\n...AIR QUALITY ADVISORY FROM THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL\nQUALITY FOR Boundary, Bonner, & Shoshone...\n\n* WHAT...Air Quality Advisory because of degraded air quality. Air\nQuality Index is forecast to be Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups.\n\n* WHERE...Boundary, Bonner, & Shoshone counties.\n\n* WHEN...Until 12pm PST 8/15/2025.\n\n* IMPACTS...Members of sensitive groups may experience health\neffects. The general public is less likely to be affected.",
        "instruction": "Air pollutants can cause breathing difficulties for children, the\nelderly, as well as persons with respiratory problems. Those\nindividuals who are sensitive to increased particulate matter or\nsmoke are encouraged to avoid prolonged or strenuous outdoor activity\nduring this advisory. Open burning is prohibited by air quality rule.\nIt is also recommended that all other individuals limit prolonged or\nstrenuous activity outdoors.\n\nTHIS STATEMENT IS ISSUED BY THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL\nQUALITY, AIR QUALITY GROUP\n\nFOR MORE INFORMATION, CONTACT DEQ's Coeur d'Alene Regional Office at\n(208) 769-1422.",

        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 7:51PM EDT until August 14 at 9:30PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "At 751 PM EDT, the public reported North Pine Grove Rd flooded.\nBetween 3 and 4 inches of rain have fallen. The expected rainfall\nrate is 1 to 1.5 inches in 30 minutes. Additional rainfall amounts\nof 1 to 2 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is\nongoing or expected to begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Public reported.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas,\nhighways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor\ndrainage and low-lying areas.\n\nSome locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nVirginia Beach, Kempsville, Regent University, Virginia Wesleyan\nUniversity, Norfolk, Chesapeake, Princess Anne, Norfolk\nInternational, Princess Anne Plaza, Gallups Corner, London Bridge,\nOceana NAS, Bayside, Oceana, Macons Corner, Mount Pleasant,\nGreenbrier, Pungo, Rudee Heights and North Virginia Beach.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads.         "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Wilmington NC",
        "headline": "Marine Weather Statement issued August 14 at 7:50PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC",
        "description": "The areas affected include...\nCoastal waters from Cape Fear NC to Little River Inlet SC out 20\nnm...\nCoastal waters from Little River Inlet to Murrells Inlet SC out 20\nnm...\nCoastal waters from Murrells Inlet to South Santee River SC out 20\nnm...\nWaters from Cape Fear NC to Little River Inlet SC from 20 to 40\nnm...\nWaters from Little River Inlet to Murrells Inlet SC from 20 to 40\nnm...\nWaters from Murrells Inlet NC to South Santee River SC from 20 to\n40 nm...\n\nAt 749 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms, capable\nof producing winds to around 30 knots and waterspouts. These\nthunderstorms were located along a line extending from near Jungle\nto 7 nm northwest of Yawkey South Island, moving east at 15 knots.",
        "instruction": "Mariners can expect gusty winds to around 30 knots, locally higher\nwaves, and lightning strikes. Boaters should seek safe harbor\nimmediately until these storms pass. If caught on the open water,\nprepare for deteriorating conditions. Make sure you and your crew are\nwearing properly fitted life jackets.\n\nThese storms may produce a waterspout. A Special Marine Warning may\nbe needed.\n\nThese strong thunderstorms will likely produce winds to around 30\nknots, and could pose a serious hazard for boaters. A Special Marine\nWarning may eventually be required if a waterspout occurs. Boaters\nshould consider heading for shore before these strong thunderstorms\narrive.",

        "senderName": "NWS Memphis TN",
        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 6:48PM CDT until August 14 at 8:45PM CDT by NWS Memphis TN",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of North Mississippi, including the following\ncounties, Coahoma, Quitman, Tallahatchie and Yalobusha.\n\n* WHEN...Until 845 PM CDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 648 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Up to 2 inches of rain have\nfallen.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nCharleston, Tutwiler, Lambert, Crowder, Webb, Sumner, Vance,\nPaynes, Dublin, Scobey, Oakland, Glendora, Effie, Waverly,\nTippo, Brazil, Mikoma, Stover, Distall and Swan Lake.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Be aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "description": "At 647 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Marshall,\nmoving south at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected.         "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nTo report severe weather contact your nearest law enforcement agency.\nThey will send your report to the National Weather Service office in\nSioux Falls.",

        "senderName": "NWS Nashville TN",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 6:46PM CDT until August 14 at 8:45PM CDT by NWS Nashville TN",
        "description": "FFWOHX\n\nThe National Weather Service in Nashville has issued a\n\n* Flash Flood Warning for...\nCentral Wayne County in middle Tennessee...\n\n* Until 845 PM CDT.\n\n* At 646 PM CDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing\nheavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain\nhave fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 1.5 inches are\npossible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected\nto begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban\nareas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as\nother poor drainage and low-lying areas.\n\n* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nWaynesboro.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Memphis TN",
        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 6:46PM CDT by NWS Memphis TN",
        "description": "At 646 PM CDT, Doppler radar was tracking a strong thunderstorm over\nWebb, or 16 miles northeast of Ruleville, moving east at 5 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 40 mph and pea size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor hail damage to vegetation is\npossible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nCharleston, Tutwiler, Lambert, Crowder, Webb, Sumner, Paynes, Dublin,\nVance, Sunnyside, Glendora, Mattson, Counts, Distall, Mims, Swan\nLake, Denton, Brazil, Beaver Dam, and Albin.",
        "instruction": "If outdoors, consider seeking shelter inside a building.\n\nTorrential rainfall is also occurring with this storm and may lead to\nlocalized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\nroadways.\n\nFrequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with this storm.\nLightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe\nshelter inside a building or vehicle.",

        "senderName": "NWS Wakefield VA",
        "headline": "Special Marine Warning issued August 14 at 7:44PM EDT until August 14 at 8:45PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "SMWAKQ\n\nThe National Weather Service in Wakefield has issued a\n\n* Special Marine Warning for...\nChesapeake Bay from Little Creek VA to Cape Henry VA including the\nChesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel...\nChesapeake Bay from New Point Comfort to Little Creek VA...\nChesapeake Bay from Windmill Point to New Point Comfort VA...\nJames River from James River Bridge to Hampton Roads\nBridge-Tunnel...\nJames River from Jamestown to the James River Bridge...\nYork River...\n\n* Until 845 PM EDT.\n\n* At 743 PM EDT, a strong thunderstorm was located near Tue Marshes\nLight, moving east at 10 knots.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts 34 knots or greater.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Small craft could be damaged in briefly higher winds and\nsuddenly higher waves.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nChesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel, New Point Comfort, Cape Henry,\nThimble Shoals, Tue Marshes Light, Hampton Flats, The Hump,\nWilloughby Bay, Sewells Point, Cabbage Patch, Cape Charles Harbor,\n1st Island Bay Bridge, Latimer Shoal, Plantation Light, Poquoson,\nDominion Pier, Kiptopeke Concrete Ships, Hampton Roads Bridge\nTunnel, York Spit Reef, and Buoy 36a.",
        "instruction": "Move to safe harbor until hazardous weather passes.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 5:44PM MDT by NWS Denver CO",
        "description": "At 544 PM MDT, Doppler radar was tracking an area of strong\nthunderstorms extending from near Keota to near Adena School, or\nextending from 36 miles northwest of Fort Morgan to 7 miles south of\nFort Morgan, moving northeast at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts up to 50 mph and pea size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects. Minor damage to outdoor objects is possible.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nFort Morgan, Brush, Log Lane Village, Hillrose, New Raymer,\nStoneham, Antelope Springs, Snyder, Keota, Pawnee Buttes, Adena\nSchool, Buckingham, Fort Morgan Airport and Union.",
        "instruction": "Monitor the weather situation closely and be alert for threatening\nweather conditions.\n\nPrepare for sudden gusty winds. Secure loose objects and move to a\nsafe shelter inside a building or vehicle.",

        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 7:44PM EDT until August 14 at 9:45PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of southwest Georgia, including the following\ncounties, Baker and Mitchell.\n\n* WHEN...Until 945 PM EDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 744 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Between 2 and 3 inches of rain\nhave fallen.\n- Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are expected\nover the area. This additional rain will result in minor\nflooding.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nNewton, Camilla, Hawkinstown, Hoggard Mill, Hopeful, Elmodel\nWma, Mimsville, Branchville, Mitchell Co A/P and Bethany.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.",

        "headline": "Special Weather Statement issued August 14 at 7:44PM EDT by NWS Miami FL",
        "description": "At 744 PM EDT, National Weather Service meteorologists were tracking\nstrong thunderstorms along a line extending from near Ave Maria to\nWest Toll Gate On Alligator Alley to Marco Island Airport. Movement\nwas west at 20 mph.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts of 45 to 50 mph.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around\nunsecured objects.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nNaples, Marco Island, Ave Maria, Golden Gate Estates, Belle Meade,\nOrangetree, Golden Gate, East Naples, Lely Resort, Big Corkscrew\nIsland, Vineyards, Royal Palm Hammock, Naples Park, Marco Island\nAirport, Naples Manor, West Toll Gate On Alligator Alley, North\nNaples, Pelican Bay, Lely, and Rookery Bay Aquatic Preserve.",
        "instruction": "These winds can down small tree limbs and branches, and blow around\nunsecured small objects. Seek shelter in a safe building until the\nstorm passes.\n\nTorrential rainfall is also occurring with these storms and may lead\nto localized flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded\nroadways.\n\nFrequent cloud to ground lightning is occurring with these storms.\nLightning can strike 10 miles away from a thunderstorm. Seek a safe\nshelter inside a building or vehicle.",

        "senderName": "NWS Sioux Falls SD",
        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 6:42PM CDT until August 14 at 7:30PM CDT by NWS Sioux Falls SD",
        "description": "At 641 PM CDT, a severe thunderstorm was located near Ghent, or near\nMarshall, moving south at 10 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to\nroofs, siding, and trees.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nMarshall, Camden State Park and Russell.",
        "instruction": "Remain alert for a possible tornado! Tornadoes can develop quickly\nfrom severe thunderstorms. If you spot a tornado go at once into the\nbasement or small central room in a sturdy structure.\n\nFor your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nTo report severe weather contact your nearest law enforcement agency.\nThey will send your report to the National Weather Service office in\nSioux Falls.",
        "response": "Shelter",

        "event": "Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Grand Forks ND",
        "headline": "Flood Warning issued August 14 at 6:41PM CDT until August 18 at 5:30AM CDT by NWS Grand Forks ND",
        "description": "...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in\nMinnesota...\n\nBuffalo River near Dilworth affecting Clay County.\n\n* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.\n\n* WHERE...Buffalo River near Dilworth.\n\n* WHEN...Until Monday morning.\n\n* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Gage not accessible above 15 feet.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 6:00 PM CDT Thursday the stage was 15.4 feet.\n- Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours\nending at 6:00 PM CDT Thursday was 15.6 feet.\n- Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage\nSaturday evening and continue falling to 6.3 feet Thursday,\nAugust 21.\n- Flood stage is 13.0 feet.",
        "instruction": "Safety message - Turn around, don't drown. Don't travel through\nflooded areas. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.\n\nAdditional information is available at www.weather.gov.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "event": "Flash Flood Warning",
        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Wakefield VA",
        "headline": "Flash Flood Warning issued August 14 at 7:39PM EDT until August 14 at 9:30PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "At 739 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy\nrain across the warned area. Between 3 and 4 inches of rain have\nfallen. The expected rainfall rate is 1 to 1.5 inches in 30 minutes.\nAdditional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible in the\nwarned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.\n\nHAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas,\nhighways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor\ndrainage and low-lying areas.\n\nSome locations that will experience flash flooding include...\nVirginia Beach, Kempsville, Regent University, Virginia Wesleyan\nUniversity, Norfolk, Chesapeake, Princess Anne, Norfolk\nInternational, Princess Anne Plaza, Gallups Corner, London Bridge,\nOceana NAS, Bayside, Oceana, Macons Corner, Mount Pleasant,\nGreenbrier, Pungo, Rudee Heights and North Virginia Beach.",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.\n\nPlease report flooding by calling 757-899-2415, posting to the NWS\nWakefield Facebook page, or using X @NWSWAKEFIELDVA.",
        "response": "Avoid",
