        "headline": "Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued August 14 at 7:38PM EDT until August 14 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA",
        "description": "At 737 PM EDT, severe thunderstorms were located along a line\nextending from near Marshfield to East Bridgewater to Foxborough,\nmoving south at 15 mph.\n\nHAZARD...60 mph wind gusts and quarter size hail.\n\nSOURCE...Radar indicated.\n\nIMPACT...Hail damage to vehicles is expected. Expect wind damage to\ntrees and power lines.\n\nLocations impacted include...\nBrockton, Taunton, Weymouth, Braintree, Randolph, Franklin, North\nAttleborough, Stoughton, Bridgewater, Marshfield, Attleboro, Walpole,\nMansfield, Middleborough, Easton, Hingham, Canton, Norton, Scituate,\nand Pembroke.",
        "instruction": "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a\nbuilding.\n\nContinuous cloud to ground lightning is occurring with these storms.\nMove indoors immediately. Lightning is one of nature's leading\nkillers. Remember, if you can hear thunder, you are close enough to\nbe struck by lightning.\n\nTorrential rainfall is occurring with these storms, and may lead to\nflash flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flooded roadways.",
        "response": "Shelter",

        "sender": "w-nws.webmaster@noaa.gov",
        "senderName": "NWS Jacksonville FL",
        "headline": "Special Marine Warning issued August 14 at 7:33PM EDT until August 14 at 8:30PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL",
        "description": "SMWJAX\n\nThe National Weather Service in Jacksonville has issued a\n\n* Special Marine Warning for...\nCoastal waters from Altamaha Sound to Fernandina Beach FL out 20\nNM...\n\n* Until 830 PM EDT.\n\n* At 732 PM EDT, a strong thunderstorm was located over St Simons\nIsland Village, or over St. Simons Island, moving east at 20 knots.\n\nHAZARD...Wind gusts 34 knots or greater.\n\nSOURCE...Radar.\n\nIMPACT...Small craft could be damaged in briefly higher winds and\nsuddenly higher waves.\n\n* Locations impacted include...\nSt Simons Island Village, St Simons Sound Buoy 9, St. Simons\nIsland, Jekyll Island, and Buoy F.",
        "instruction": "Move to safe harbor until hazardous weather passes. If your vessel is\ncaught offshore, immediately secure for heavy weather. Ensure all\ncrew members are wearing USCG approved Type I life jackets and\nnonessential crew are below decks. Deploy jack lines and harnesses if\navailable. Check life saving equipment, including batteries on\nhandheld radios, for readiness.\n\nFrequent lightning is occurring with this storm. If caught on the\nopen water stay below deck if possible, keep away from ungrounded\nmetal objects.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "senderName": "NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM",
        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 5:31PM MDT until August 14 at 6:30PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...A portion of southwest New Mexico, including the following\ncounty, Luna.\n\n* WHEN...Until 630 PM MDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\nRises in small streams and normally dry arroyos. Dangerous flows\nover low-water crossings. Water over roadways.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 531 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain\nhas fallen.\n- Additional rainfall of up to 0.5 inches is expected over the\narea. This additional rain will result in minor flooding.\n- Some locations that may experience flooding include...\nHermanas and Carzalia Valley.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.\n\nRemain alert for flooding even in locations not receiving rain.\nArroyos, streams, and rivers can become raging killer currents in a\nmatter of minutes, even from distant rainfall.",
        "response": "Avoid",

        "headline": "Flood Advisory issued August 14 at 7:30PM EDT until August 14 at 10:30PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA",
        "description": "* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.\n\n* WHERE...Portions of northeast North Carolina, including the\nfollowing counties, Gates and Hertford and southeast Virginia,\nincluding the following county and independent city, City of\nSuffolk and Southampton.\n\n* WHEN...Until 1030 PM EDT.\n\n* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas.\n\n* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...\n- At 730 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to\nthunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin\nshortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain\nhave fallen.\n- Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.5 inches are expected\nover the area. This additional rain will result in minor\nflooding.\n- Some locations that will experience flooding include...\nSuffolk, Como, Whaleyville, Cleopus, Reynoldson, Dort,\nSomerton, Topsy, Wyanoke, Drum Hill, Riddicksville and\nRiverdale.\n- http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood",
        "instruction": "Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood\ndeaths occur in vehicles.\n\nBe especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the\ndangers of flooding. Do not stay in areas subject to flooding when\nwater begins rising.\n\nBe aware of your surroundings and do not drive on flooded roads.",
